intro: Acrodiclidium camara, commonly known as the red sandalwood, is a member of the Burseraceae family and is native to tropical regions of Africa. It is a small to medium-sized tree that typically grows in dry, sandy soils. The plant is characterized by its smooth, reddish-barked trunk and small, leathery leaves. Its flowers are unisexual, with separate male and female flowers on the same plant, and it produces small, round fruits containing a single seed. Due to its ornamental value and historical use in traditional medicine, it is sometimes cultivated for its aesthetic and practical properties.
